In electromagnetic theory, the electric and magnetic phenomena are related to each other. Therefore the dimensions of electric and magnetic quantities must also be related to each other. In the questions below, \( [E] \) and \( [B] \) stand for dimensions for electric and magnetic fields respectively, while \( [\epsilon_0] \) and \( [\mu_0] \) stand for dimensions of permittivity and permeability of free space respectively. \( [L] \) and \( [T] \) stand for dimensions of length and time respectively. All the quantities are given in SI units.

data.value: If the measurement errors in all the independent quantities are known, then it is possible to determine the error in any dependent quantity. This is done by the use of series expansion and truncating the expansion to the first power of the error. For example, consider the relation \( z = \frac{x}{y} \) If the errors in x, y and z are \( \Delta x \), \( \Delta y \), \( \Delta z \) respectively, then$$ z \pm \Delta z = \frac{x \pm \Delta x}{y \pm \Delta y} = \frac{x}{y} (1 \pm \frac{\Delta x}{x})(1 \pm \frac{\Delta y}{y})^{-1}$$The series expansion for \( (1 \pm \frac{\Delta y}{y})^{-1} \), to the first power of \( \frac{\Delta y}{y} \) is \( 1 \mp \frac{\Delta y}{y} \). The relative errors in independent quantities are added. So the error in z will be $$ \Delta z = z (\frac{\Delta x}{x} + \frac{\Delta y}{y}) $$The above derivation makes the assumption that \( \frac{\Delta x}{x} \ll 1\) and \( \frac{\Delta y}{y} \ll 1 \). Therefore the higher powers of these quantities are neglected

question.statement: Consider the ratio \( r = \frac{1 + \alpha}{1 - \alpha} \) to be determined by measuring a dimensionless quantity \( \alpha \). If the error in measurement of \( \alpha \) is \( \Delta \alpha (\frac{\Delta \alpha}{\alpha} \ll 1) \), then what is the error \( \Delta r \) in determining \( r \)?
